encodingDesc.p: This document is a simplified "true-to-text" XML version of The Spanish Curate based on Pennsylvania State University's annotated copy of the 1647 Beaumont & Fletcher first folio. Major textual elements and attributes have been captured based on how they appear in the folio. Whenever possible, editorial interventions have been minimalized or avoided entirely. This document is meant to serve as a pedagogical tool by which students of Early Modern literature can learn to construct edited XML versions of the play.

projectDesc.p: The Digital Beaumont & Fletcher (1647) is a collaborative editorial project aimed at making many of the rarely edited—and, as a result, rarely taught—plays in the “Beaumont & Fletcher” canon accessible to student readers and freely available online for classroom use. This project was inspired by the distinctive copy of Comedies and Tragedies Written by Francis Beavmont And Iohn Fletcher Gentlemen (1647) held by Penn State University's Eberly Family Special Collections Library. In addition to preserving evidence of ownership dating to as early as 1703, Penn State's copy of this printed play collection also includes three plays with handwritten marginalia, suggesting that the book might have been used to facilitate performance in the late seventeenth century. This project is also motivated by a desire to make the texts and other features of this book more widely known and readable. As a first step, the whole volume has now been fully digitized, thanks to the department of Preservation, Conservation, and Digitization at Penn State Libraries.

handNote.p: This edition of The Spanish Curate contains the marginal notes found in the Penn State Libraries' copy of the 1647 folio. These manuscript notes are particually attentive to the performance of the play, and prepare actors for entrances and emphasize stage directions throughout the text. These manuscript notes have been added to the text without modernization spelling of puncuation.

div.head: Act Two. Scene One.
div.stage: Enter Leandro [disguised] (with a letter written out), Milanes, and Arsenio

lg.l: Can anything, but wonder?
Wonder on;
I am as ye see and what will follow, gentlemen.
Why dost thou put on this form? What can this do?
Thou lookest most sillily.
Like a young Clerk Clerk,
A half-pinned-puppy half-pinned-puppy: half-confined puppy that would write for a royal.
Is this a commanding shape to win a beauty?
To what use? What occasion?
Peace, ye are fools;
More silly than my outside. Seems ye are ignorant;
They that pretend to wonders must weave cunningly.
What manner of access can this get? Or, if gotten,
What credit in her eyes?
Will ye but leave me?
Me thinks a young man and a handsome gentleman;
(But sure thou art lunatic). Me thinks a brave man
That would catch cunningly the beams of beauty,
And so distribute'em unto his comfort,
Should like himself appear: young, high, and buxom buxom: youthful, large in stature, and indulgent.
And in the brightest form.
Ye are cozened, (gentlemen);Lop: Diegoe be ready.
Neither do I believe this, nor will follow it,
Thus I am. I will begin my voyage.
When you love, launch it out in silks and velvets.
I'll love in serge, and will outgo your satins
To get upon my great horse and appear.
The sign of such a man, and trot my measures,
Or fiddle out whole frosty nights, (my friends),
Under the window while my teeth keep tune,
I hold no handsomeness. Let me get in
There trot and fiddle where I may have fair play.
But how get in?
Leave that to me, your patience;
I have some toys here that I dare well trust to:
I have smelt a vicar vicar: earthly representative of God out; they call him Lopez.
We do confess it.
Weak, simple men. This vicar to this lawyer
Is the most inward Damon.
What can this do?
We know the fellow and he dwells there.
So?
A poor, thin thief: he help? He? Hang the vicar
Can reading of an — — prefer thee?

Thou art dead-sick in love dead-sick in love: completely in love; as in love as one can be, and he'll pray for thee. : In the first folio, the line "Thou art dead-sick in love, and hee'l pray for thee" is assigned to Leandro. However, since Leandro is the one in love, and has been made fun of by Arsenio in the lines prior, this line should actually be assigned to Arsenio. The line is assigned to Arsenio in the second folio and in Bowers' scholarly edition, an editorial choice that I agree with and thus have implimented in this modernization.
Have patience, (gentlemen); I say this vicar,
This thing I say is all one with the close Bartolus,
(For so they call the lawyer), or his nature
Which I have studied by relation:
And make no doubt I shall hit handsomely,
Will I work cunningly and home make no doubt...and home: I will work carefully, cleverly, and head home: understand me.
Next, pray, leave me, leave me to my fortune.

Difficilia pulchra Difficilia pulchra: Troublesome beauty is the literal translation, but Leandro is referring to Amaranta's beauty being worth the difficulty of the task of getting to her., thats my motto, (gentlemen)
I'll win this diamond from the rock and wear her
Or — —
Peace, the vicar: send ye a full sail, sir.
There's your confessor, but what shall be your penance?
A fool's head if I fail and so forsake me.
You shall hear from me daily.
lg.note: In the first folio, the lines "A fools head if I fail and so forsake me. / You shall heare from me daily." are assigned to Arsenio. However, since Leandro is the one attempting to seduce Amaranta, he is the one that could fail. Leandro has also come up with an alternative identity and would be away from Arsenio and Milanes; he promises to give them daily updates here. These lines are assigned to Leandro in the second folio and in Bowers' scholarly edition, an editorial choice that I agree with and thus have implimented in this modernization.

lg.l: We will be ready.
Thin world indeed.
I'll let him breathe and mark him;
No man would think a stranger as I am
Should reap any great commodity from his pigbelly.
Poor stirring for poor vicars.
And poor sextons sextons: manager of church.
We pray and pray, but to no purpose;
Those that enjoy our lands, choke our devotions.
Our poor, thin stipends make us arrant dunces arrant dunces: wandering idiots.
If you live miserably, how shall we do, (master);
That are fed only with the sound of prayers?
We rise and ring the bells to get good stomachs.
And must be fain to eat the ropes with reverence.
When was there a Christening Christening: administered baptism, (Diego)?
Not this ten weeks:
Alas, they have forgot to get children, (master).
The wars, the seas, and usury undo us,
Takes off our minds, our edges, blunts our plough-shares,
They eat nothing here, but herbs and get nothing green sauce.
There are some poor labourers that perhaps
Once in seven year, with helping one another,
Produce some few pinned–Butter–prints pinned-Butter-prints: (slang) weak babies or children that scare hold
The Christening neither.
Your gallants, they get honour,
A strange fantastical birth, to defraud the vicar,
And the camp christens their issues, or the courtesans courtesans: sex workers, prostitutes,
'Tis a lewd time.
They are so hard-hearted here, too;
They will not die; there's nothing got by burials.
Diego, the air's too pure, they cannot perish.
To have a thin stipend, and an everlasting parish,
Lord what a torment 'tis!
Good sensible master,
You are allowed to pray against all weathers,
(Both foul and fair as you shall find occasion).
Why not against all airs airs: humeralism?
That's not i'th'canons canons: rules of the Catholic Church,
I would it had: 'tis out of our way forty pence pence: monetary unity and coin of England.
'Tis strange, they are starved too, yet they will not die here;
They will not earth earth: Diego is lamenting that the people of the parish will not die, and thus cannot be buried, which would earn him money.. A good stout plague amongst 'um,
Or half a dozen new fantastical fevers
That would turn up their heels by whole-sale, (master).
And take the doctors too, in their grave counsels;
How merrily would my bells go then How merrily...go then: Diego is referring to the death-bell, a bell tolled to announce a death.?
Peace, Diego.
The doctors are our friends, let's please them well;
For though they kill but slow, they are certain, (Diego),
We must remove into a muddy air muddy air: polluted air,
A most contagious climate.
We must certain,
An air that is the nursery of agues.
Such agues, (master), that will shake men's souls out,

Ne're stay for possets possets: drinks made from hot milk curdled with alcohol often drunk for medicinal purposes, nor good old wives' plasters plasters: bandages covered in a medicinal substance applied to the skin.
Gouts and dead palsies Gouts...palsies: arthritis and paralysis or weakness.
The dead does well at all times,
Yet gouts will hang an arise a long time, (master).
The pox, or English surfets, if we had 'em;
Those are rich marl marl: ground-up, they make a churchyard fat,
And make the sexton sing, they never miss, sir.
Then wills and funeral sermons come in season wills...season: Lopez is referring to the wills and funerals that come after people's death, which benefit him as the Curate.,
And feasts that makes us frolick.
Would I could see' em.

And though I weep i'th' pulpit pulpit: "A raised, enclosed platform in a church or chapel (or sometimes on the outside of the building), sometimes with a canopy and usually with a desk, seat, etc., from which the preacher delivers a sermon, or from which (in some denominations) the officiating minister conducts the service." for my brother,
Yet, (Diego), here I laugh.
The cause requires it.
Since people left to die I am dunce, (Diego).
'Tis a strange thing; I have forgot to dig, too.
A pretious pair of youths; I must make toward 'em.
Who's that? Look out, it seems he would speak to us.
I hope a marriage or some will to make, (Diego).
My friend, your business?
'Tis to that grave, gentleman;
Bless your good learning, (sir).
And bless you also;
He bears a promising face, there's some hope toward.
I have a letter to your worship.
Well sir,
From whence, I pray you?

From Nova Hispania
Nova Hispania: Literally translates to "New Spain". Explain the relationship between Spain and the New World., sir,
And from an ancient friendancient friend: old friend of yours.
'Tis well, (sir),
'Tis very well. [aside to Diego]. The devil a-one I know there.
Take heed of a snap, snap: swindler (sir), has a cozening countenance cozening countenance: deceitful expression
I do not like his way.

sp.speaker: Lopez.

lg.l: Let him go forward.

Cantabit Vacuus Cantabit Vacuus: Cantabit Vacuus is a refrence to the longer Latin phrase, "Cantabit vacuus coram latrone viator" which translates to "the empty-handed traveler sings in front of the robber." Lopez is telling Diego to take the chance in trusting Leandro as they have little to lose., they that have nothing fear nothing;
All I have to lose, (Diego), is my learning,
And when he has gotten that, he may put it in a nutshell nutshell: something of little value.

div.p:
Since my arrival fromCordobato these
parts, I have written diverse letters unto you but as
yet received no answer of any. [Lopez:] (Good and very good). And
although so great a forgetfulness might cause a want in my
due correspondence, yet the desire I have still to serve you
must more prevail with me [Lopez:] (Better and better: the Devil
a man know I yet) and therefore with the present occasion
offered I am willing to crave a continuance of the favours,
which I have heretofore received from you and do recom-
mend my Son, Leandro the Bearer to you with request
that he may be admitted in that university till such time
as I shall arrive at home; his studies he will make you ac-
quainted withal. This kindness shall supply the want of your
slackness: and so Heaven keep you.
div.closer:
Yours,
Alonzo Tiveria Alonzo Tiveria: The character Alonzo Tiveria is character made up by Leandro to trick Diego and Lopez into helping him into Bartolus' house so he can meet Amaranta.

sp.l: A very ancient friend of mine I take it,
For till this hour I never heard his name, yet.

lg.l: You look, (sir), as if ye had forgot my father.
No, no, I look as I would remember him,
For that I never remembered, I cannot forget, (sir)
The same, (sir).
And now i'th' Indies Spanish colony in the Caribbean: India?
Yes.
He may be anywhere,
For ought I consider.
Think again, (sir).
You were students both at one time in Salamanca Salamanca: city in Northwestern Spain,
And, as I take it, chamber fellows chamber-fellows: roommates.
Ha?
Nay, sure you must remember.
Would I could.
I have heard him say, you were gossips, too.
Very likely,
You did not hear him say, to whom? For we students
May often-times over-reach our memories.
Do'st thou remember, (Diego), this same Signiour?
Thou hast been mine these twenty years.
Remember?
Why, this fellow would make ye mad: Nova Hispania?
And Signiour Tiveria? what are these?
He may as well name ye friends out of Cathay Cathay: China
Take heed, I beseech your worship: do you hear, (my friend)>
You have no letters for me?
Not any letter,
But I was charged to do my father's love
To the old honest sexton, Diego. Are you he, (sir?)
Ha? Have I friends, and know 'em not? My name is Diego,
But if either I remember you or your father
Or Nova Hispania, (I was never there, sir),
Or any kindred that you have—for heaven-sake, master,
Let's cast about a little, and consider,
We may dream out our time.
It seems I am deceived, (sir).
Yet, that you are Don Lopez, all men tell me,
That curate here, and have been some time, (sir).
And you, the sexton, Diego, such I am sent too,
The letter tells as much. Maybe they are dead,
And you of the like name succeed succeed: inherited. I thank ye, gentlemen,
Ye have done honestly, in telling truth,
I might have been forward else. For that Lopez
That was my father's friend, I had a charge,
(A charge of money), to deliver, (gentlemen),
Five hundred Ducats, a poor small gratuity.
But since you are not he.
Good sir, let me think;
I pray ye be patient. Pray ye stay a little.

Nay, let me remember, I beseech ye stay, sir.In the first folio, the lines "Good sir, let me think; / I oray ye be patient." are assigned to Leandro's speech above. However, the second folio assigns the the lines to Lopez, combining the lines previously assigned to Leandro to Lopez's original lines, "Pray ye stay a little, / Nay, let me remember, I beseech ye stay, sir." I decided to follow the second folio's edits. Turner also changes the lines to follow the second folio's arrangment.
An honest noble friend, that sends so lovingly;
An old friend too; I shall remember sure, sir.
Thou sayst true, Diego.
'Pray ye consider quickly,
Do, do, by any means, me thinks already
A grave, staid gentleman grave, staid Gentleman: serious man settled in his character comes to my memory.
He's old indeed, sir.
With a goodly white beard,
(For now he must be so: I know he must be)
Signior Alonzo, (master).
I begin to have him.
'Has been from hence, about some twenty years, (sir).
Some five and twenty, (sir).
You say most true, (sir).
Just to an hour: 'tis now just five and twenty;
A fine striaght timbered man, and a brave soldier,
He married: let me see—
De Castro's daughter.
The very same.
Thou art a very rascal,
De Castro is the Turk to thee, or anything.
The money rubs 'em into strange remembrances,
For as many ducats more they would remember Adam.
Give me your hand, you are welcome to your country.
Now I remember plainly, manifestly manifestly: unmistakably,
As freshly, as if yesterday I had seen him.
Most heartily welcome, sinful that I am,
Most sinful man, why should I lose this gentleman?
This loving old companion? We had all one soul, sir,
He dwelt here hard by, at a handsome—
Farm, sir.
You say most true.
Alonzo Tiveria;
Lord, Lord, that time should play the treacherous knave thus?
Why, he was the only friend I had in Spain, (sir).
I knew your mother too, a handsome gentlewoman,
She was married very young: I married 'em.

I do remember now the masques masques: A form of courtly dramatic entertainment, often richly symbolic, in which music and dancing played a substantial part, costumes and stage machinery tended to be elaborate, and the audience might be invited to contribute to the action or the dancing. and sportssports: diversions or entertainments then,
The fireworks, and the fine delights; good faith, sir,
Now I look in your face whose eyes are those, Diego?
Nay, if he be not just Alonzo's picture—
Lord, how I blush for these two impundents impudents: shameless individuals?
Well, gentleman, I think your name's Leandro?
It is indeed, (sir).
Gra'-mercy Gra'-mercy: many thanks letter thou hadst never known else.
I have dandled dandled: moved a child up and down in their arms or knees ye, and kissed ye and played with ye
A hundred, and a hundred times, and danced ye,
And swung ye in my bell-ropes, ye loved swinging.
A sweet boy.
Sweet lying knaves,
What would these do for thousands?
A wondrous sweet boy then it was. See now
Time that consumes us, shoots him up still sweeter.
How does the noble gentleman? How fares he?
When shall we see him? when will he bless his country?
Oh, very shortly, sir, till his return,
He has sent me over to your charge.
And welcome,
Nay, you shall know you are welcome to your friend, sir.
And to my study, (sir), which must be the law,
To further which, he would entreat your care
To plant me in the favour of some man
That's expert in that knowledge. For his pains
I have three hundred ducats more: for my diet,
Enough, (sir), to defray defray: meet the expense of me: which I am charged
To take still, as I use it, from your custody.
I have the money ready, and I am weary.
Sit down, sit down, and once more ye are most welcome.
The law you have hit upon most happily,
Here is a master in that art, Bartolus,
A neighbour by, to him I will prefer ye,
A learned man, and my most loving neighbour;
I'll do ye faithfull service, (sir).
He's an ass,
And so we'll use him; he shall be a lawyer.
But if ever he recover this money again— before, Diego.
And get some pretty pittance pittance: allowance: my pupil's hungry.
Pray ye, sir, unlade unlade: remove a burden from me.
I'll refresh ye, sir;
When ye want, you know your exchequer.
If all this get me but access, I am happy.
Come, I am tender tender: affectionate of ye.
I'll go with ye.
[aside] To have this fort betrayed these fools must slice me.

div.head: Scene Two.

lg.l: My Amaranta, a retired sweet life,
Private and close, and still, and housewifely
Becomes a wife; sets off the grace of a woman
At home to be believed both young and handsome,
As lilies that are cased in crystal glasses,
Makes up the wonder. Show it abroad; 'tis stale stale: past its prime,
And still and the more eyes cheapen it 'tis more slobbered slobbered: drooled over,
And what needs windows open to inviting
Or evening terraces, to take opinions?More be rea
When the most wholesome air, (my wife), blows inward,
When good thoughts are the noblest companions,
And old chaste stories, (wife), the best discourses.
But why do I talk thus, that you know thy nature?
You know your own disease: distrust and jealousies;
And those two give these lessons not good meaning.
What trial is there of my honesty,
When I am mewed mewed: confined at home? To what end, husband,
Serves all the virtuous thoughts and chaste behaviours
Without their uses? Then they are known most excellent
When, by their contraries they are set off, and burnished.
If ye both hold me fair and chaste and virtuous,
Let me go feareless out, and win that greatness greatness: inherent nobility.
These seeds grow not in shades and concealed places
Set 'em i'th' heat of all, then they rise glorious.
Peace, you are too loud.
You are too covetous covetous: greedy;
If that be ranked a virtue, you have a rich one.
Set me (like other lawyers' wives) off handsomely,
Attended as I ought, and as they have it.
My coach, my people, and my handsome women,
My will, in honest things.
Peace, Amaranta.
They have content, rich clothes, and that secures' em,
Binds Binds: ties; unites through obligation, to their careful husbands, their observanceobservance: attentive care.
They are merry, ride abroad, meet, laugh.
Thou shalt, too.
And freely may converse with proper gentlemen,
Suffer temptations daily to their honour.
You are now too far again. Thou shalt have anything.
Let me but lay up for a handsome office,
And then, my Amaranta—
Here's a thing now:
Ye place as pleasure to me: all my retinue retinue: group of people in the service of another:
My chambermaid chambermaid: assistant to a Lady, my kitchen maidkitchen maid: assistant to a cook, my friend,
And what she fails in, I must do myself.
A foil to set my beauty off, I thank ye,
You will place the devil next for a companion.

div.stage: Enter [Egla]. Because, in a later scene, a servant is called by his given name, I decided to do the same elsewhere in the play. This stage direction originally marked an entrance by a "Woman-Moore", but I have changed this stage direction and subsequent stage directions and speakers accordingly..

lg.l: No more such words, (good wife).
What would you have, (Maid maid: a female servant)?
Master curate, and the sexton, and a stranger, (sir),
Attend to speak with your worship.
A stranger?
You had best to be jealous of the man you know not.
'Prithee, no more of that.
'Pray ye go out to 'em,
That will be safest for ye. I am well here,
I only love your peace, and serve like a slave for it.
No, no, thou shalt not; 'tis some honest client
Rich and litigious, the curate has brought to me.
'Prithee go in, (my duckduck: A term of endearment, also used in Shakespeare's Midsummer Night's Dream.). I'll but speak to 'em,
And return instantly.
I am commanded,
One day you will know my sufferance.—— Exit [Amaranta].
And reward it.
So, so, fast bind, fast findfast bind, fast find: (proverb) by locking something up, you can find it quickly.; Come in my neighbours,
My loving neighbours. Pray ye come in, ye are welcome.
Bless your good reverence.
Good day, good master curate,
And neighbour, Diego, welcome. What's your business?
And 'pray ye be short, (good friends), the time is precious.
Welcome, good sir.
To be short, then, with your mastership,
(For I know your several hours, are full of business);
We have brought ye this young man, of honest parents,
And of an honest face.
It seems so, (neighbours).
But to what end?
To be your pupil, (sir);
Your servant, if you please.
I have travelled far, sir.
To seek a worthy man—
Alas, good gentleman,
I am a poor man, and a private too,
Unfit to keep a servant of your reckoning.
My house a little cottage, and scarce able
To hold myselfe and those poor few live under it.
Besides, you must not blame me, gentleman.
If I were able to receive a servant,
To be a little scrupulous of his dealing
For in these times—
'Pray let me answer that, (sir).
Here is five hundred ducats to secure him,
He cannot want, (sir), to make good his credit,
Good gold, and coin.
And that's an honest pledge;
Yet sure, that needs not, for his face, and carriagecarriage: manner
Seem to declare an inbred honesty.
And for I have a ripe mind to the law, (sir),
(In which I understand you live a master).
The least poor corner in your house, poor bed, (sir),
(Let me not seem intruding to your worship)
With some books to instruct me, and your counsel,
Shall I rest most content with. Other acquaintance
Than your grave presence and the grounds of law
I dare not covet, nor I will not seek, (sir),
For surely mine own nature desires privacy.
Next, for your monthly painspains: troubles, difficulties (to show my thanks),
I do proportion out some twenty ducats.
As I grow riperriper: richer, more: three hundred now, (sir),
To show my love to learning, and my master,
My diet, I'll defraydefray: cover, pay too, without trouble.
Note but his mind to learning.
I do strangely, yes. [aside] And I like it too, thanks to his money.
Would he would live with me, and learn to dig, too.
A wondrous, modest man, (sir).
So it seems,
His dear love to his study must be nourished;
Neighbour, he's like to proveprove: try, endeavour.
With your good counsel
And with your diligence, as you will ply him;
His parents, when they know your care—
Come hither.
An honester young man, your worship ne're kept,
But he is too bashful—
Oh, I like him better.
Say I should undertake ye, which indeed, (sir),
Will be no little straightness to my living,
Considering my affairs, and my small house,(sir),
For I see some promises that pull me to ye.
Could you content yourself, at first thus meanly,
To lie hard, in and out part of my house, (sir)?
For I have not many lodgings to allow ye;
And study should be still remote from company;
A little fire sometimes too, to refresh ye;
A student must be frugal: sometimes lights too,
According to your labour.
Anything, (sir),
That's dry, and wholesome; I am no bred-wantonbred-wanton: raised to be unmanageable.
Then I receive you: but I must desire ye
To keep within your confinesconfines: boundaries, limits.
EverEver: Always , sir.
There's the gold, and ever be your servant,
Take it and give me books. May I but prove, (sir),
According to my wish, and these shall multiply.
Do study hard. Pray ye take him in, and settle him,
He's only fit for you. Show him his cell,cell: room (sir).
Take a good heart; and when ye are a cunning lawyer,-
I'll sell my bells and you shall prove it lawful.
Come, sir, with me. Neighbors, I thank your diligence.
I'll come sometimes and crack a case with ye.
Welcome—
Here's money got with ease. Here: spend that jovially,
And pray for the fool, the founder founder: supporter, maintainer.
Many more fools
I heartily pray may follow his example,
Lawyers, or lubberslubbers: clumsy, stupid people, or of what conditioncondition: circumstance,
And many such sweet friends in Nova Hispania.
It will do well. Let 'em but send their moneys,
Come from what quarter of the world, I care not,
I'll know 'em instantly. Nay, I'll be a kin to 'em;
I cannot miss a man, that sends me money:
Let him lawlaw: litigate there? Long as his ducats last, boy,
I'll grace him, and preferprefer: promote him.
I'll turn tradeturn trade: change occupation, (master),
And now live by the living, let the dead stink:
'Tis a poor stinking trade.
If the young fool now
Should chance to chop upon his fair wife ,(Diego).
And handle her case, (master). That's a law point;
A point would make him start and put on his spectacles;
A hidden point, were worth the canvassing.
Now surely, surely, I should love him, (Diego)
And love him heartily. Nay, I should love myself,
